awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Microfluidic Mm-Wave RF Devices with Integrated Actuation
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical:

Wireless technology has traditionally used radio waves to transmit and receive data. High data rate demands driven by mobile communications are being addressed by emerging wireless communication systems operating at new frequency bands. A large frequency spectrum is available at terahertz (THz) frequencies, also known as mm-wave. However, mm-wave systems face challenges such as reduction in signal strength with distance or blockage and reflection of signals. These challenges drive the development of new antennas and devices that can maximize the signal strength with high efficiency and rapidly adapt their operation. This project focuses on an innovative microfluidic based approach to enable such mm-wave antennas and devices with reduced cost and enhanced efficiency. These novel devices will be enabled by integrated compact actuation mechanisms. Advances from this project can immediately benefit wireless communication as well as emerging mm-wave applications such as identification tags and smart appliances. The interdisciplinary nature of the program is expected to offer unique training and research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students. The PIs will develop new curriculum content that focuses on problems faced by engineers working on interdisciplinary projects. The project also plans to expand research opportunities for high-school students and students from underrepresented minorities.

Technical:

Microfluidic reconfiguration techniques have drawn interest to address efficiency, tunability, and power handling issues of reconfigurable radio-frequency (RF) devices. Unfortunately, the majority of the proposed devices cannot operate in mm-wave bands due to the challenges in manufacturing, RF modeling, and utilization of liquid metals exhibiting lower conductivities and oxidization issues. This project focuses on a more recent microfluidic reconfiguration technique that is suitable for mm-wave band operation due to its reliance on selectively metallized plates (SMPs) repositionable within microfluidic channels. The major goal is to integrate novel actuation mechanisms with the SMP based microfluidic devices and enable their practical operation in mm-wave frequencies to achieve superior performances in efficiency, tunability, and power handling. Two distinct actuation mechanisms based on piezoelectric disks and electrowetting (EW) will be investigated to allow discovery of a broad range of capabilities. Through refinement of fabrication methods, flow characterizations, and RF design; the piezoelectric actuation will be optimized to achieve maximum RF reconfiguration speed. EW-based actuation will create a microfluidic linear stepper motor for addressing the high precision motion requirements. The trade-offs in plate alignment accuracy, selection of liquids, device geometry and RF performance will be investigated to establish the fundamental design and fabrication guidelines. In the RF design domain, the project will introduce novel capabilities by modeling the motion-dependent RF parasitics of SMPs. The proposed actuation and modeling methods are applicable for a large class of mm-wave devices. This three-year program is particularly tailored for addressing the challenging needs imposed by the mm-wave beam-steering antenna arrays. The program aims to investigate novel switches, phase shifters, and beamforming networks by addressing their design (i.e. RF parasitics modeling, size reduction, high efficiency, power handling) and actuation aspects (integration, resilience to vibration and impact, lifetime, speed).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Wireless communication at mm-wave frequency bands is highly attractive for achieving high data rates and accommodating a large number of users simultaneously. However, wireless propagation in mm-wave bands presents significant challenges due to the high path loss and limited penetration through objects. Therefore, it is crucial to develop novel mm-wave device technologies that can minimize component losses, enhance efficiency, and offer reconfigurability to meet the needs of multiple systems simultaneously. Additionally, these devices must handle high transmit power levels without requiring large, bulky heat sinks. Reconfiguration of high frequency devices using microfluidics technology holds promise in addressing these challenges. However, current microfluidics-based techniques are largely restricted to lower frequency bands because they rely on bulky pumps for device actuation and/or liquid metals which have lower conductivity and are difficult to actuate reliably.

This project introduced novel reconfigurable mm-wave devices that utilized microfluidics-based repositioning of selectively metalized plates (SMPs) within microfluidic channels. The actuation mechanism for the SMPs was innovatively redesigned to be internal, employing piezoelectric disks, and eliminating the reliance on bulky external microfluidic pumps. The project successfully demonstrated the first reconfigurable microfluidic devices operating within the mm-wave band with an integrated actuation mechanism. One of these devices was a frequency-agile mm-wave bandpass filter that provided continuous and independent control over both bandwidth and center frequency. This filter was capable of reconfiguring its center frequency from 38 GHz to 28 GHz while offering fractional bandwidth control in the range of 7% to 12%. Its reconfiguration speed was measured at 260 MHz/ms, and it could handle continuous 5W mm-wave power without requiring a heat sink. Additionally, the reliability of these devices was demonstrated to exceed 12 million reconfiguration cycles.

Another device demonstration was a novel mm-wave phase shifter operating at 28 GHz, achieving its full phase shift range with only a 100 μm displacement of its SMP using an integrated piezoelectric-based actuation mechanism. The operation of this device was also modeled with a new circuit representation that accounted for circuit parasitic loadings associated with the motion of the SMP. Similar to the bandpass filter, the phase shifter demonstrated the capability to handle nearly 5W of continuous mm-wave power without requiring a heat sink. The power handling capability is attributed to the device's high efficiency and low loss. The phase shifter was also tested for resilience against vibrations and orientation changes (relative to gravity) and was found to maintain stable performance under these conditions.   

Multiples of the mm-wave phase shifters were combined into a group that utilized a single SMP with strategically customized metallization patterns. This design was proposed to implement an analog beamforming feed network capable of steering the beam of a mm-wave antenna array using only a single integrated actuation mechanism. Beam steering was achieved within an SMP is actuation range of -100 to 100 μm, enabling a beam steering speed of 75 ms to cover the entire scan range. Additionally, the project investigated other devices, including mm-wave multi-throw switches and alternative phase shifter designs, which could potentially offer lower losses and/or wider bandwidths.

The grant supported 3 PhD students and 1 undergraduate student. These students gained valuable skills in antenna and RF circuit modeling, microfabrication, hardware assembly, and testing the performance of mm-wave antennas and devices. The project outcomes were disseminated through publications and presentations. Additionally, key topics such as reconfigurable device design approaches, microfluidics-based reconfiguration, and power handling of RF/ mm-wave devices were covered as topics in multiple courses to inform a broader student body about the challenges and technological advancements necessary for the wide-scale deployment of mm-wave band communications.
